metadata.official_name: State University of New York at Binghamton

strategic_profile.executive_summary: SUNY Binghamton University is a public research university consistently recognized for its academic excellence, particularly in business, engineering, and the sciences. It offers a selective, rigorous education with a strong emphasis on undergraduate research and career preparation, attracting high-achieving students seeking a 'public Ivy' experience.
strategic_profile.market_position: A highly-regarded public Ivy, known for strong academics, value, and research focus within the SUNY system.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Binghamton seeks intellectually curious and highly motivated students who have demonstrated strong academic performance and a commitment to engaging with the campus community. A holistic review process considers GPA, test scores (if submitted), essay quality, extracurricular involvement, and potential for contribution to the university's diverse environment.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Strong value proposition as a public university with a 'private' feel.
Increasing selectivity and national recognition, particularly for STEM and Business programs.
Geographic isolation can be a double-edged sword: fosters community but limits immediate urban amenities.
Continued investment in research infrastructure and opportunities for students.
Emphasizes a well-rounded student profile beyond just academics for admissions.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Active and engaged, with a mix of residential life, Greek organizations, and numerous student clubs. The campus is somewhat isolated, leading to a strong on-campus community feel, but also relies on shuttle services for off-campus entertainment.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Relatively isolated campus; most students live on or near campus. University-provided shuttle services connect main campus with downtown Binghamton and student housing areas, mitigating the need for personal vehicles for daily activities, though a car is useful for exploring the wider region.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Significant focus on undergraduate and graduate research across all disciplines, particularly in engineering, health sciences, and sustainable communities. Numerous research centers and institutes provide opportunities for student involvement and contribute to the university's R1 research designation.

current_status.test_policy_details: Binghamton University is test-optional, meaning standardized test scores (SAT or ACT) are not required for first-year applicants. Students have the choice to submit scores, and if they do, Binghamton will superscore, combining the highest section scores from multiple administrations of the same test type (SAT or ACT). Self-reported SAT scores are accepted, but official scores are required upon enrollment. For transfer students, test scores are optional if they have completed fewer than 24 semester credits or 36 quarter credits since high school graduation. International students may submit ACT/SAT scores for academic review or to fulfill English proficiency requirements, though other tests are also accepted for English proficiency. Binghamton does not require the ACT writing or science sections, or the SAT essay section.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Data for Fall 2025 is from Binghamton University's Office of Institutional Research (University Total figures)
Data for Fall 2024 is from Binghamton University's Office of Institutional Research (University Total figures)
Data for Fall 2023 is from Binghamton University's Office of Institutional Research (University Total figures)
Data for Fall 2022 is from Binghamton University's Office of Institutional Research (University Total figures)
Data for Fall 2021 is from Binghamton University's Office of Institutional Research (University Total figures)

gpa.notes: Binghamton University's official class profile for Fall 2024 reports a weighted high school GPA mid-50% of 93–98 (on a 100-point scale). Some admitted students have weighted GPAs above 4.0. The university considers a holistic approach to admissions, with many admitted students being at the top of their high school class.

testing.policy_note: Binghamton University is test-optional. For students who choose to submit scores, Binghamton will combine the highest section scores from multiple administrations of the same test type (SAT or ACT), meaning superscore is accepted for the same test. Scores are not combined across different test types.

demographics.notes: Legacy defined as alumni children. Binghamton University does not consider alumni relations in its admissions process.

men.note: Data for Fall 2021 first-time, first-year (freshman) admissions from Common Data Set 2021-22.

women.note: Data for Fall 2021 first-time, first-year (freshman) admissions from Common Data Set 2021-22.

colleges.name: Harpur College of Arts and Sciences

majors.name: Biology
prerequisite_courses: BIOL 113 - Intro to Cell & Molecular Biol
BIOL 114 - Intro to Organisms & Pops Biol
CHEM 104 - General Chemistry I (or CHEM 107 - General Chemistry for Science Majors I)
CHEM 105 - General Chemistry II (or CHEM 108 - General Chemistry for Science Majors II)
MATH 147 - Elementary Statistics (or MATH 224 - Differential Calculus)

core_courses: BIOL 113 - Intro to Cell & Molecular Biol
BIOL 114 - Intro to Organisms & Pops Biol
electives: BIOL 347 - Human Physiology (if BIOL 251 is taken)
curriculum.major_units: 52 credits (including prerequisites, general education, and upper-level biology courses)

majors.notes: Students should declare their major after completing 12 college credits, with 8 from BIOL 113, BIOL 114, CHEM 104/107, CHEM 105/108, MATH 147. AP Statistics is not accepted for MATH 147. A minimum of 28 credits in BIOL courses numbered 300-level and above, including the two upper-level core courses, must be taken in Harpur College. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

majors.name: Psychology

core_courses: PSYC 243 - Statistical Analysis & Design (or equivalent statistics course)
electives: Upper-level psychology courses across different areas (e.g., developmental, cognitive, social, clinical, neuroscience)

majors.notes: Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026. Psychology is listed as a popular major.

majors.name: Economics
prerequisite_courses: MATH 147 - Elementary Statistics (or equivalent statistics course)
MATH 224 - Differential Calculus (or equivalent calculus course)

electives: Upper-level economics courses (e.g., international economics, public finance, labor economics)
curriculum.major_units: Minimum 36 credits in Economics courses (including prerequisites).

majors.notes: Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026. Economics is listed as a popular major.

colleges.name: Thomas J. Watson College of Engineering and Applied Science

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: CS 120 - Intermediate Programming (if not taken with CS 210)
CS 210 - Data Structures (if not taken with CS 120)

core_courses: CS 301 - Professional Skills for Computer Scientists
CS 375 - Introduction to Analysis of Algorithms

majors.notes: Minimum 2.0 (C) grade-point average in computer science major courses and a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 required for the degree. A grade of C- or better in required computer science courses is needed to satisfy prerequisites, except for CS 301. Students with AP credit and strong CS background may take CS 120 and CS 210 in the first semester. Otherwise, CS 110 in Fall, then CS 120 or CS 210 in Spring is recommended. Computer Science is considered highly competitive. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026, CS Course Guidesheet 2025-26.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
prerequisite_courses: ME 273 - Statics and Strength of Materials
weeder_courses: ME 273 - Statics and Strength of Materials

core_courses: ME 273 - Statics and Strength of Materials
curriculum.major_units: Around 60-70 credits in Mechanical Engineering and related sciences.

majors.notes: Students enter as second-year students from the Engineering Design Division, or as second-year or third-year transfer students. ME 273, ME 211 & 274 must be completed with a C- or better to satisfy prerequisites. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026, ME Course Guidesheet 2025-26.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering

curriculum.major_units: Around 60-70 credits in Electrical Engineering and related sciences.

majors.notes: Students typically enter as second-year students from the Engineering Design Division. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026, EE Course Guidesheet 2025-26.

prerequisite_courses: BIOL 113 - Intro to Cell & Molecular Biol
BIOL 114 - Intro to Organisms & Pops Biol

curriculum.major_units: Around 60-70 credits in Biomedical Engineering and related sciences.

majors.notes: Students typically enter as second-year students from the Engineering Design Division. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

core_courses: ISE 487 - Senior Project I (Industrial and Systems Engineering)
ISE 488 - Senior Project II (Industrial and Systems Engineering)
curriculum.major_units: Around 60-70 credits in Industrial and Systems Engineering and related sciences.

notable_professors: Feng Ning (Associate Professor, research in Enterprise Systems, Industrial Automation and Control)
majors.notes: Students typically enter as second-year students from the Engineering Design Division. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

majors.name: Computer Engineering
majors.notes: Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

majors.name: Business Administration
prerequisite_courses: MATH 220 - Calculus For Business & Mgmt (or MATH 223 & 224, or MATH 224 & 225)
CQS 112 - Statistics For Management (or MATH 147 or PSYC 243)
MGMT 111 - Intro Decision Making in MGMT
BLS 111 - Legal Environment Of Mgmt I

core_courses: MGMT 111 - Intro Decision Making in MGMT
BLS 111 - Legal Environment Of Mgmt I
curriculum.major_units: 63 credits of liberal arts and sciences coursework, plus approximately 63 credits of business coursework (including 45 credits of upper-level coursework).

majors.notes: Minimum 2.0 cumulative GPA and 2.0 GPA in required BSBA courses. Concentrations have specific GPA requirements, e.g., Business Analytics requires a 3.5 cumulative Binghamton GPA and a B- or better in CQS 312. The School of Management is highly competitive. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

colleges.name: Decker College of Nursing and Health Sciences

majors.name: Nursing
prerequisite_courses: Two Composition (C or J gen ed) courses

core_courses: NURS 401 - Leadership and Management in Nursing

notable_professors: Mario R. Ortiz (Dean, Professor of Nursing, research in community health nursing and patient-centered medical homes)
Heidi Ewen (Associate Professor, Division of Nursing)
Betsy Perry (Clinical Assistant Professor, Division of Nursing)
Megan Seevers (Clinical Instructor, Division of Nursing)
majors.notes: The Nursing program is highly competitive. Applicants for internal transfer must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 and a minimum 3.0 average in the prerequisite requirements. Prerequisites must be completed with a minimum grade of C- prior to enrolling in upper-division nursing courses. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

colleges.name: College of Community and Public Affairs

majors.name: Human Development

core_courses: HDEV 200 - Research Methods in Human Development
HDEV 300-level courses in areas such as childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and aging
curriculum.major_units: Around 40-44 credits in Human Development and related fields.

majors.notes: Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026. Human Development is listed as a popular major.

majors.name: Social Work
prerequisite_courses: One course in Economics, Political Science, or Anthropology
majors.special_requirements: Interview may be required for admission to the professional year.

core_courses: SW 310 - Social Welfare Policy and Services
SW 320 - Human Behavior and the Social Environment I
SW 321 - Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
curriculum.major_units: Minimum 51 credits in Social Work and related fields.

majors.notes: A minimum GPA of 2.5 is typically required for admission to the professional Social Work program. Students usually apply in their sophomore year. Data source: Binghamton University Academic Guide 2025-2026.

colleges.name: School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

application_deadlines.notes: Decisions are typically released by January 15th. EOP applicants are not eligible for Early Action and should use the SUNY Application.
Decisions are typically released by April 1st.

supplemental_requirements.details: Required for pre-professional BFA programs. After Admissions receives the application, students will be emailed to confirm their intent to pursue a BFA and will be required to respond to a short form to indicate their intended program. All portfolio materials must be submitted through the application status checker.

Required for pre-professional BMUS programs. After Admissions receives the application, students will be emailed to confirm their intent to pursue a BMUS and will be required to respond to a short form to indicate their intended program. All audition/portfolio materials must be submitted through the application status checker.
EOP applicants may be requested to complete and submit additional academic and financial application materials. EOP applicants are not eligible for Early Action.
Students may submit special talent supplements.

holistic_review_factors.specific_differentiators: Binghamton University is test-optional and offers an optional 60-90 second video submission. The university emphasizes intellectual curiosity, innovation, and a proactive approach in its students.

essay_prompts.prompt: Some students have a background, identity, interest, or talent that is so meaningful they believe their application would be incomplete without it. If this sounds like you, then please share your story.
brainstorming_questions: What core aspect of your identity or experience have you not fully expressed elsewhere in your application?
Is there a unique passion or talent you possess that truly defines you or your aspirations?
How has this background, identity, interest, or talent shaped your worldview or decision-making?
Can you recall a specific moment or series of events that solidified the importance of this aspect in your life?
What unique perspective or contribution would this part of your story allow you to bring to a college community?

key_success_factors: Strong academic record with challenging coursework
Demonstrated passion in 1-2 areas rather than scattered activities
red_flags: Significant Decline in Senior Year Grades
Listing Extracurricular Activities Without Demonstrating Depth or Impact
Unimpressive or Generic Letters of Recommendation

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive colleges/majors if not set on highly competitive programs: If your academic profile isn't exceptionally strong for programs like Computer Science, Engineering, Management (SOM), or Nursing (Decker), consider applying to less competitive schools within Binghamton, such as Harpur College of Arts and Sciences or the College of Community and Public Affairs (CCPA). These are generally considered "easiest to get into". You can often transfer internally or declare a desired major later, especially within Harpur, once admitted to the university.

Consider applying undeclared within Harpur College of Arts and Sciences: Harpur College is the largest and most diverse, offering over 60 Bachelor's degree programs. Applying undeclared to Harpur can be a viable strategy, as it's generally one of the easier schools to get into. Once enrolled, students have opportunities to explore various fields through introductory classes, clubs, and career development resources before declaring a major, typically during their second year.

Leverage the Binghamton University Scholars Program for guaranteed major choice: If you are accepted into the Binghamton University Scholars Program, you are granted the privilege of choosing any major in any school or college at Binghamton. This guarantees admission to your desired major, provided you apply no later than March 10 of your first year and seek advice from the relevant advising office.

Research major-specific admission requirements and competitiveness before applying: Some programs at Binghamton are highly competitive, such as those in the Watson College of Engineering and Applied Science, the Decker College of Nursing and Health Sciences, and the School of Management (SOM). If you are aiming for one of these, it's crucial to have a strong academic record, particularly in relevant coursework (e.g., high grades in math and science for engineering). Understanding the specific prerequisites and average accepted GPAs or test scores for your target major can significantly inform your application strategy.

Excel in target major-related courses and highlight relevant experiences: For competitive majors, demonstrating strong performance in subjects related to your desired field is important. Additionally, extracurricular activities, volunteer work, and strong recommendations can enhance your application, as Binghamton takes a holistic approach to admissions. This is especially true if your GPA or test scores are not at the very top, as these elements can showcase your character and commitment to your chosen field.
college_ranking_tactics: Align your academic choice with personal interests and career goals. Students are advised to explore different majors and programs by taking introductory classes to fulfill general education requirements, assessing their enjoyment of the material, and considering how the learning applies to potential careers. Utilizing resources like academic advisors and the Fleishman Center for Career and Professional Development can help evaluate options and narrow down interests.

Evaluate the specific academic environment and resources of each school or program. Consider factors such as emphasis on interdisciplinary studies, research opportunities (like the Freshman Research Immersion program for STEM students), availability of specialized clinics or facilities, and the overall academic rigor and support services offered (e.g., tutoring, writing centers).

Consider the characteristics of the residential communities. Binghamton University has a residential college system with six distinct communities. Students can evaluate these based on factors such as convenience to campus facilities, room quality, availability of amenities like air conditioning, and the social atmosphere or "spirit" of each community. For example, Dickinson Community is often noted for its convenience and spacious rooms, while College-In-the-Woods is recognized for its charm and central location.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If your academic profile isn't strong enough for highly competitive programs like Computer Science, Engineering, Management, or Nursing, consider applying to less competitive schools within Binghamton, such as Harpur College of Arts and Sciences or the College of Community and Public Affairs. Internal transfers or major declarations are often possible later.
essay_tips: Focus on a Personalized Narrative and Show, Don't Tell: Admissions committees want to understand you beyond your grades. Craft a personal statement that reveals your unique qualities, experiences, and aspirations. Instead of simply stating you are "smart," demonstrate moments where you were challenged, how you overcame obstacles, and what you learned from those experiences. Use concrete examples and vivid descriptions to illustrate your points, rather than making general statements.

Highlight Extracurriculars and Contributions to a Community: Binghamton University takes a holistic approach to admissions, considering factors beyond academics. Your essay is an opportunity to showcase your involvement in hobbies, sports, volunteering, or work. Emphasize any leadership roles you've held and how these experiences have shaped you and prepared you to contribute to the Binghamton community.

Address Undecided Interests (if applicable) Thoughtfully: If you are applying as an undecided major, use your essay to explain *why* you are undecided and what areas or subjects you are potentially interested in exploring. This demonstrates self-awareness and a proactive approach to your academic future, rather than a lack of direction.

Convey Your Fit and Reasons for Choosing Binghamton (Implicitly): While Binghamton may primarily use the Common Application essay or a general SUNY supplemental essay, your personal statement should still implicitly convey why you are a good fit for the university. Discuss how your background and interests align with what Binghamton offers, showcasing your potential contributions to its diverse and dynamic campus life.

analyst_takeaways.insight: SUNY Binghamton is a highly selective institution with acceptance rates generally ranging from 38% to 45%. Successful applicants typically have strong academic records, with average GPAs of 3.6 or higher and competitive SAT/ACT scores (if submitted).
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should aim for a strong GPA in rigorous courses and consider submitting competitive SAT/ACT scores if they strengthen their application. Applying Early Action by November 1st may also improve chances of acceptance.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Binghamton University is recognized as a 'Public Ivy' with rigorous academics, particularly in STEM and business programs, and offers over 130 academic programs with strong research opportunities.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants interested in STEM or business should highlight relevant coursework, projects, and experiences. Emphasizing intellectual curiosity, a desire for research opportunities, and specific academic interests within their chosen field can demonstrate alignment with Binghamton's academic strengths.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The university fosters a collaborative, welcoming, and inclusive campus environment with a vibrant social life, numerous clubs, and distinctive living-learning residential communities.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should showcase their involvement in extracurricular activities, leadership roles, and experiences that demonstrate teamwork and a desire to contribute positively to a community. Highlighting how they would engage with campus life and specific residential communities can be beneficial.

financials.notes: The Excelsior Scholarship Program can make Binghamton tuition-free for many New York residents whose families have a net taxable income of up to $125,000.

scholarships.name: Binghamton University Achievement Scholarship (Full In-State Cost of Attendance)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (typically November 1 for Early Action, January 15 for Regular Decision for Fall enrollment)
scholarships.benefits: Covers full in-state cost of attendance for up to four years, renewable with specified GPA.

scholarships.name: Binghamton University Achievement Scholarship (Partial Award)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (typically November 1 for Early Action, January 15 for Regular Decision for Fall enrollment)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for up to four years with specified GPA.

scholarships.name: President's, Provost's, and Dean's Scholarships
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (typically November 1 for Early Action, January 15 for Regular Decision for Fall enrollment)
scholarships.benefits: Competitive four-year awards, renewable with minimum GPA and full-time enrollment.

scholarships.name: International Student Scholarships
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years, based on academic achievements.

scholarships.name: NYS Excelsior Scholarship Program
scholarships.deadline: Determined by Higher Education Services Corporation (HESC)
scholarships.benefits: Tuition-free attendance at a SUNY college for eligible New York State residents.

scholarships.name: NYS STEM Incentive Program
scholarships.deadline: Determined by Higher Education Services Corporation (HESC)
scholarships.benefits: Full tuition for top 10% of NY high school class pursuing STEM degrees, requires living and working in NY in a STEM field for five years after graduation.

scholarships.name: Unger Family Scholarship (School of Management)
scholarships.benefits: Awarded based on academic merit, leadership, and financial need.

ap_policy.usage: AP credits can be used to fulfill general education or major/minor requirements, and satisfy some major prerequisites. A maximum of 32 exam credits from all sources (AP, IB, CLEP, A-Levels) can be applied towards a degree.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with 5+ grant credit; scores of 4 or 5 receive 4 credits, and scores of 6 or 7 receive 8 credits. The foreign language general education requirement can be satisfied by a score of 4-7 on either Higher Level or Standard Level exams.

transfer_credit_policy.restrictions: For guaranteed admission to Harpur College of Arts & Sciences, a minimum GPA of 3.2 is required for AA or AS degree holders from SUNY two-year colleges; GPAs between 2.8 and 3.19 are considered on a case-by-case basis. International Baccalaureate (IB) Diploma holders can receive up to 32 credits, provided they complete the diploma with 30 or more points and achieve a score of 5 or higher on at least three Higher Level exams. While a specific '60 unit cap for community college credits' directly from SUNY Binghamton was not explicitly found, transfer agreements with other SUNY institutions indicate that a minimum of 60 credits from an associate degree will typically be applied towards a bachelor's degree for junior standing, and overall maximum transfer credits from all sources can range up to 90 credits depending on the program and institution.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework
Demonstrated passion in 1-2 areas rather than scattered activities
common_activities: Binghamton University offers a vibrant and active campus life with over 300 student-run clubs and organizations catering to diverse interests such as academics, professions, culture, arts, and sports. Greek life also has a significant presence on campus. The university fosters a strong sense of community through its six unique living-and-learning residential communities, each with its own culture and traditions.
essay_tips: Focus on a Personalized Narrative and Show, Don't Tell: Admissions committees want to understand you beyond your grades. Craft a personal statement that reveals your unique qualities, experiences, and aspirations. Instead of simply stating you are "smart," demonstrate moments where you were challenged, how you overcame obstacles, and what you learned from those experiences. Use concrete examples and vivid descriptions to illustrate your points, rather than making general statements.

Highlight Extracurriculars and Contributions to a Community: Binghamton University takes a holistic approach to admissions, considering factors beyond academics. Your essay is an opportunity to showcase your involvement in hobbies, sports, volunteering, or work. Emphasize any leadership roles you've held and how these experiences have shaped you and prepared you to contribute to the Binghamton community.

Address Undecided Interests (if applicable) Thoughtfully: If you are applying as an undecided major, use your essay to explain *why* you are undecided and what areas or subjects you are potentially interested in exploring. This demonstrates self-awareness and a proactive approach to your academic future, rather than a lack of direction.

Convey Your Fit and Reasons for Choosing Binghamton (Implicitly): While Binghamton may primarily use the Common Application essay or a general SUNY supplemental essay, your personal statement should still implicitly convey why you are a good fit for the university. Discuss how your background and interests align with what Binghamton offers, showcasing your potential contributions to its diverse and dynamic campus life.
red_flags: Significant Decline in Senior Year Grades
Listing Extracurricular Activities Without Demonstrating Depth or Impact
Unimpressive or Generic Letters of Recommendation

insights.insight: SUNY Binghamton is a highly selective institution with acceptance rates generally ranging from 38% to 45%. Successful applicants typically have strong academic records, with average GPAs of 3.6 or higher and competitive SAT/ACT scores (if submitted).
Binghamton University is recognized as a 'Public Ivy' with rigorous academics, particularly in STEM and business programs, and offers over 130 academic programs with strong research opportunities.
The university fosters a collaborative, welcoming, and inclusive campus environment with a vibrant social life, numerous clubs, and distinctive living-learning residential communities.

outcomes.notes: Binghamton University ranks in the 94th percentile for median earnings 10 years after enrollment. The employment rate of 95.0% is for 5 years after graduation, with 93% employed 1 year after graduation.

student_retention.notes: Ranks in the top 10% of institutions nationwide for graduation rates.

campus_life.social_environment: Binghamton University fosters a vibrant social life with numerous clubs and organizations, alongside a significant Greek life presence. The campus atmosphere is described as bright and energetic, promoting collaboration over competition among students. While overall lively, some commuter students express a desire for enhanced community engagement.
campus_life.transportation_impact: The campus is walkable, and students benefit from extensive free transportation options. This includes the student-run Off Campus College Transport (OCCT) and Broome County (BC) Transit buses, both accessible with a valid University ID. A continuous campus shuttle service facilitates movement around the main campus. Additionally, a bike-share program and a carpooling database (511NY Rideshare) are available to further aid student mobility.
campus_life.research_impact: Binghamton University offers strong undergraduate research opportunities and mentorship, positioning itself with one of the nation's most vibrant research programs. This includes unique first-year immersion projects for STEM students, providing three-semester, real-life research experiences in specialized fields such as Biogeochemistry and Neuroscience. The university houses 33 organized research centers and institutes for advanced studies, notably including the New York State Center of Excellence in Small Scale Systems Integration and Packaging (S3IP). Professors are noted for being supportive and encouraging, often providing mentorship opportunities.
campus_life.housing_overview: Binghamton University offers a diverse range of academic programs across its six colleges and schools. Undergraduate housing is structured around a residential college system, distinct from the academic colleges, with first-year students required to live on campus. Graduate students typically reside off-campus. First-year students are required to live in one of five unique residential communities: College-in-the-Woods (CIW), Dickinson Community, Hinman College, Mountainview College, and Newing College. Each community fosters a sense of belonging with its own culture, traditions, student government, dining hall, quad, and recreational facilities. Room styles vary across these communities, including corridor-style doubles (College-in-the-Woods, Dickinson, Newing), suite-style (Hinman, Mountainview, some CIW), and flat-style (Dickinson). Facilities often include laundry rooms, kitchens, common lounges, and academic support spaces. The Apartments Community, comprising Susquehanna and Hillside, offers more independent living for upperclassmen and transfer students, with apartments featuring single bedrooms, full kitchens, and common areas in two-, four-, or six-person configurations. Binghamton also offers specialty housing options such as gender-inclusive and quiet living. All graduate students at Binghamton University live off-campus. Resources are available through Off-Campus Programs and Services to assist with finding housing, roommates, and navigating renter safety. Many graduate students choose to live in Binghamton (particularly the west side or downtown), Johnson City, or the nearby Village of Endicott. Off-campus options can include luxury student apartments, private rentals, or shared housing.

housing_by_college.college_name: Harpur College of Arts and Sciences
housing_by_college.housing_profile: Undergraduate students reside in one of Binghamton University's five traditional residential communities (College-in-the-Woods, Dickinson Community, Hinman College, Mountainview College, Newing College) offering corridor, suite, or flat-style rooms with shared bathrooms or in-suite/in-flat bathrooms, along with dining halls, recreational spaces, and academic support. Upperclassmen may opt for the Apartments Community (Susquehanna and Hillside) with single bedrooms and full kitchens. Graduate students live off-campus in the surrounding Binghamton area.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and broad-minded individuals interested in diverse fields across humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and mathematics. Students are often engaged in interdisciplinary studies and value a strong liberal arts foundation.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a comprehensive liberal arts education with numerous academic pathways and opportunities for exploration across a wide range of disciplines.

housing_by_college.college_name: College of Community and Public Affairs (CCPA)
housing_by_college.housing_profile: Undergraduate students reside in one of Binghamton University's five traditional residential communities offering various room styles and amenities. Upperclassmen may opt for the Apartments Community with more independent living. Graduate students live off-campus in the surrounding Binghamton area, with many engaging in community-focused living.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Service-oriented and socially conscious individuals driven to make a positive impact in their communities. Students are often passionate about social justice, public service, human development, and education.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Best for students committed to public good, community engagement, and careers in social work, public administration, human development, and education, who thrive in hands-on, real-world experiences.

housing_by_college.college_name: Decker College of Nursing and Health Sciences
housing_by_college.housing_profile: Undergraduate nursing and health sciences students reside in Binghamton University's residential communities. Upperclassmen and transfers may opt for apartment-style living on campus. Graduate students in nursing and health sciences programs live off-campus. The college itself features modern facilities with advanced simulation and lab environments for practical training.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Compassionate and dedicated individuals aspiring to careers in healthcare. Students are focused on patient-centered care, clinical practice, and often engage in interprofessional collaboration across health disciplines.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for highly motivated students seeking rigorous healthcare education with extensive clinical experiences and access to state-of-the-art simulation facilities, particularly those interested in nursing, physical therapy, occupational therapy, public health, or speech-language pathology.

housing_by_college.housing_profile: Undergraduate management students reside in Binghamton University's residential communities, with options ranging from corridor to suite and apartment styles. Upperclassmen can also choose the Apartments Community. Graduate students pursuing an MBA or other management degrees live off-campus in the local area.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Ambitious, career-focused, and collaborative individuals interested in business, accounting, finance, and management. Many are driven to gain real-world experience through internships and case competitions.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a strong, hands-on business education with excellent career outcomes, particularly those aiming for roles in top firms in New York and beyond, and who value mentorship and practical application.

housing_by_college.college_name: Thomas J. Watson College of Engineering and Applied Science
housing_by_college.housing_profile: Undergraduate engineering and computer science students live in the university's residential communities, which include various dorm styles and amenities. Some residential learning communities may have an engineering theme. Upperclassmen can choose apartment-style living on campus. Graduate engineering students typically live off-campus. The college boasts modern facilities with advanced equipment and computer labs.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Problem-solvers and innovators with a strong aptitude for STEM fields. Students are drawn to hands-on design, research, and developing solutions to real-world technological challenges.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Highly recommended for students with a robust STEM background eager for an innovative curriculum, significant research opportunities, and practical experience in engineering and computer science.

housing_by_college.housing_profile: All graduate students at Binghamton University live off-campus. They typically find housing in apartments or shared houses in Binghamton (west side or downtown), Johnson City, or Endicott, with resources available through Off-Campus Programs and Services.
housing_by_college.student_archetype: Dedicated and focused individuals pursuing advanced academic or professional degrees. Students are driven by research, specialized study, and often balance their academics with professional development and social engagement through graduate student organizations.
housing_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Suitable for students seeking to deepen their expertise, engage in cutting-edge research, and advance their careers through master's or doctoral programs in a supportive academic environment.

campus_life.rankings_and_reputation: Binghamton University is frequently recognized as a "Public Ivy" due to its high academic standards and reputation. It is cited by U.S. News & World Report as one of the "nation's top 50 public universities" and a "best value public college." Forbes has ranked it as the #1 public university in New York and among the "Top 25 Public Colleges." Niche ranks it highly among Top Public Universities in America (#46 of 699) and Top Public Universities in New York (#1 of 39). QS World University Rankings 2026 placed it at #1001-1200. In the 2026 U.S. News & World Report rankings, it was recognized as the #73 best overall university and praised for its strong academic quality and affordability. The university is also frequently noted as a top public institution and a best-value college nationwide.
